segments.text: how it works, hoping that everything goes well.
One, two, three, four, five, six.
We're April the 2nd, up at Camp Creek, looking out over the lake, chatting with Ed Cooper, and now want to stop and be sure this machine is working.
Ed, would you, since we may not get your student days done today,
Hope we can.
Would you give a brief summary of your experience before you came to work on the campus with Mr. Rutter and President Williams?
Concentrating on A&M experience, is that what you mean?
Yes.
OK. My major in college was the field of wildlife conservation.
I developed a great interest in that field as a young man growing up in a natural situation in San Marcos.
Decided to major in wildlife and A&M was the only and still is the only university in the state that offers a degree program in wildlife management.
So with that in mind and not with any idea at all about what employment I would get into per se except that it would probably be with
Parks and Wildlife or Fish and Wildlife or Forest Service or National Parks.
I went into the field, enjoyed it very, very much.
I was a good student in wildlife.
And I made friends with Ari Callender, who was the Ag Extension Service Wildlife Specialist.
He was the first one they had in all of agriculture.
And when I left to serve two years with the 2nd Armored Division in Germany, Mr. Callender wrote me.

several times and said do not accept a job anywhere until you've given us a chance an extension because i'm going to retire so honoring that i went to the campus had already had an offer from parks and wildlife to be a public information officer at rockport uh at a very low salary by the way
And I liked very much when I interviewed Nolan Williamson and Hoot Gibson with the Ag Extension.
I was really impressed with the people and their attitude about work.
And I said, you know, I believe I'll go to work with you guys.
They said, we want to start you as an assistant county agent so you understand 4-H programs and how the county extension people operate in the counties.
We'll put you with Elmo V. Cook, one of our best county agents in Austin, Texas.
There'll be little towns and big towns, so you get a cross-section of agriculture there until Mr. Callender retires.
He retired in six months.
So in about middle of 1956, I came to campus, served seven years as ag extension specialist in wildlife conservation, was in the field about 50% of the time,
and had more gates opened and more doors open to meeting the good people across the state of Texas than all of the rest of my experiences put together because that's the nature of that business.
I still have friends in counties across the state because of extension work.
So I guess my best experience was the communications with people, primarily in agriculture.
I thoroughly enjoyed those seven years as wildlife specialist.
My territory was simply the state of Texas.
I wrote a newsletter to all the county extension agents with as much up-to-date information.
I told them back in the 50s that we would see a time, for example, when the leasing of property for hunting
would be super big business, and they guffawed and said, how in the hell can it be when all they do is let their friends and their family hunt?
And now without hunting in the hill country, for example, most ranchers would be out of business.
So what I predicted did happen because I knew of people's intense desire to be outdoors and away from the stress of life.
So with that background,
I decided to get rich and joined a classmate in Jacksonville, Texas, in agricultural fertilizer and limestone business.
We had the trucks to spread them.
We were going to get rich.
My arrival in Jacksonville coincided with the worst drought they've ever had there, and people simply stopped spending money on something that would burn the pastures even worse than the sun.
And so I could see the handwriting on the wall.
Got a call in from Clark Monroe, personnel director.
And John Hutchison, ag extension director, had given my name as a candidate possibly for assistant to President Earl Rutter.
And he arranged an interview.
I walked into Mr. Rutter's office.
And he said, Cooper, I understand you sell ag limestone.
He said, I've got a ranch out close to London, Texas.
You know where that is?
I said, I sure do.
He said, how much lime should I use on that ranch?
And I said, well, President Rutter, since it's entirely made of limestone already, I really don't see you wasting money on that.
And he just died laughing.
And I think that simple little off to a good start thing convinced him that I might be a type of personality that he could use in that office.
And so in 63, October of 63, I started as his administrative assistant.
replacing Dorsey Macquarie, who went over and, as you know, developed the development office.
And it had tied in with student financial aid as well with Bob Logan.
I'm not going to ask this question of any other.
What was the beginning salary as Mr. Rutter's assistant?
The Extension Service had a PhD in soil science at that time, just as I left, which was only nine months before this.
And he passed the benchmark of $10,000 in salary for the first extension specialist that had ever made $10,000.
And so I was flattered to come back at that salary, $10,000.
And at that time, we were in a pretty bad situation because the job in Jacksonville just did not pan out.
So it was a lifesaver for us.
Mr. Rutter, I learned, was really close with state money.
And if he thought he could get a guy
10, and instead of 12 or 13, he'd damn sure go for 10.
He was very close.
And then later I worked with Jack Williams, which we'll get to, but he was the other way.
If he had a person he wanted, he'd pay whatever it took.
Rudder would do his best to get it at rock bottom.
And I think that's one reason you saw a lot of retired military people on campus, because they already had an income, and he could get them for bargain rates.
I can't fuss about it, but he was damn tight.
Describe Earl Rudder as you came to know him at those first years.
What was he like, physically, emotionally, attitudinally, and so forth?
He was a laid-back kind of an individual around the office.
He was fairly moody.
And when I was his assistant, it was my habit to go in in the morning and I would have two Manila folders.
And I'd call them the happy file and the sad file.
And if I could see that far away look in his gray, steel gray eyes that something was really nagging at him, I would never get into that sad file.
Because whatever I proposed would be thumbs down.
So I'd go to the happy file and talk about easy things that we were going to do that wouldn't require any thought.
But I could read him pretty well.
He had a look about his face.
He was always signing papers, and very often while I'd visit with him in the mornings, he would continue signing papers.
And he developed a system where he wouldn't sign it, wouldn't sign anything unless it had initials from
whatever vice president was responsible in that area.
He got where he would not ask any questions if he saw Tom Cherry's signature or Clyde Freeman or whoever.
But he wouldn't sign it without him.
So he could sign papers and think at the same time.
But I could read his moods very easily.
And he was easy to get along with.
Very seldom was he ever
short, if he was really mad about something, he would just simply turn gray and shut up and not say anything.
Jack Williams was not that way.
What were Mr.
Rudder's pet peeves, if he had any?
This sounds silly, but I was close to him, and he disliked people that smoked pipes.
He said, anybody that has enough time to keep a damn pipe clean enough to smoke is not doing his job.
Another thing that he was very conservative in terms of the way people dressed.
He thought people should be dressed properly for their work or their job.
He did not, for example, allow his daughters to wear shorts at home.
He thought that parents should control most of the activities of their children who they had dates with and who they did not have dates with.
And he was, as I mentioned earlier, very close with money.
Ms. Rutter told Peggy and I a number of times that he damn sure didn't give her enough money to run that house, that household.
And that was true.
But he was just, you know, he came from the land office and he had an experience of what
happens when people lose respect for money and honesty.
And so he was just going to be very certain that everything he did was only up and up and expected the people that worked for him to be the same way.
He reveled in telling stories, certainly about his experiences in the Army and the Normandy invasion.
And if he would have a drink or two, he would invariably start talking about
about his experiences in the military.

And I've heard the names, I think at least once of every Ranger that served under him as they, and the cooperation they got with the British, he had a steel trap memory and he could remember what they ate the night before the invasion and, uh, which one's got seasick and things like that.
Steel, steel memory, steel trap memory about things like that.
And that war.
never really was over in his mind.
And until the day he died, and this might be edited out, but he still doesn't trust Germans until the day he died.
And he would try not to say anything, but when somebody had the name Levi Strom or Schaffner, he was automatically suspicious because he had such a bad experience over there with the Germans.
He admired them because they were good, but he detested them at the same time.
I think he would have felt the same way about the Japanese.
Physically, he was not quite as trim as that statue is.
Physically, okay, a basic point.
He had no interest in this world other than devoting his life to Texas A&M.
In so doing, most of it is sedentary.
What is that the right word?
Sedentary.
Sedentary.
You can do it sitting down and very often at banquet tables.
He loved to drink and often it was the wrong kind of thing for a man that had his
feed conversion ratio.
He liked Harvey Wallbangers, for example, which was a terrible syrupy kind of a drink.
That's the last thing he needed.
But he loved to have a few cocktails before his meals.
And that would give him more of an appetite.
And he really had no exercise.
And I think all of that together, the stress of the job, overweight,
and no exercise and absolutely no outside interest.
He tried to go quail hunting over on the Heap Ranch with me.
He'd walk around for an hour or so and said, when are we going to eat?
He tried to go fishing, but he was the poorest coordinated man with a rod and reel I've ever seen.
It would wrap around his head and go up into the trees.
And he just couldn't find anything to get his mind off of his job.
And I think with the combination of stress
blood pressure, eating, and the drinking that creates an appetite that goes with it.
All of those things, I think, killed him at an early age.
And he had no avocation, did he?
No.
No hobbies?
No.
None.
Let's see.
My brain just thinks of this.
Let's reach back.
Did you ever hear from him any explanation as to how or why Alan Shivers called on Earl Rudder
to come clean up the land office.
He had been Lyndon Johnson's campaign manager, so I understand.
West Texas, that's right.
It had to be smoky room politics.
And there's a whole lot of friendship behind the scenes that went on in and around Austin.
that I got really mainly from Margaret Rutter.
But they were real close to some people high in state politics through the years.
And I don't recall specifically the Shivers tie-in.
I heard a lot about Jake Pickle and John Connolly and Lyndon Johnson and all of those.
But I don't remember much about Shivers.
Because I think it was Shivers that brought him over.
to head the land office.
I believe it was, yeah.
All right, then did you ever hear how did the A&M leadership come to identify Earl Rudder to come over here in the late 50s and take charge?
Well, now that was John Connolly, wasn't it?
Well, Connolly wasn't yet governor.
No, wait a minute.
Because see, Connolly doesn't become governor until 62.
That's true.
And Rutter came, I think, in 57 and was a vice president.
Right.
And as I have understood it, the plan was clear cut.
You come and do this for a year or so, and then you become president.
And his inauguration is the spring of 1960, because I was in the procession representing my undergraduate school, Austin College.
And so he officially becomes president in 59, and the ceremony is held in early 60.
Right.
I really can't contribute to that era.
He never really talked about that to me.
So that early age, really nearly everything, seeing I was in ag extension, and really everything that I knew about him
he either talked about, and usually with me that was back to the war, was me from 63 on.
When you got there, describe his staff, the office group.
Dorsey McCrory had been his assistant.
And back to the conservative nature, Dorsey was a retired colonel in the Army.
I was assured by Clark Monroe that Dorsey would sit down with me at length and tell me how to be an assistant to President Errol Rudder.
And Dorsey's total training for me was, oh, you'll catch on.
That was it.
He refused to talk about it anymore.
And let's see, the people in the office then, we didn't have NELDA that early.
He had an executive committee that would meet on Mondays, and I went to those meetings.
And who was on that?
Oh, there'd be...
The deans and the vice presidents?
Yeah, that's right, the deans and the vice presidents, and the directors.
Ah, yes.
Because at that time, they reported, the service directors reported them.
And those were really good meetings, frank and open discussions, arguments.
Fred Benson, of course, was...
leading the pack, he had the most respect, I would say.
He was very wary about things that came from the system level.
Of course, there was bad feelings there.
Can I talk about people?
Oh, yes.
Oh, yes, please.
He said something like, you know, I can't stand Clyde Freeman.
I don't like him.
But he has never made a mistake.
that he's brought to me.
He has been right about everything that's ever come to me that he's had to interpret for me.
J.A.
Amos was the total legislative staff, which would be Beatle Bailey compared to the entire WW2 now with what they have.
You said legislative.
You meant legal.
Excuse me.
I meant the total legal staff with J.A.
Amos.
And that was down the hall, of course.
But I'm trying to think of Jerry Haught.
Jerry Haught was the main administrative secretary for him.
It was really a very small staff.
Now, you all were in the System building or the Koch building?
Started in System and then went to Koch.
And I'll never forget, I had the air conditioning
was very bad in that building.
Well, the whole building was designed poorly.
It was the worst building I think I've ever been in, except Guyon Hall.
But I said, Mr. Rutter, could I have?
I was on the west side.
Would it be OK for me to get some drapes in here to help cut the sunlight down?
All we had was Venetian blinds.
He said, no.
He said, first thing, you know every assistant on campus would want that.
And the rule was there'd be no carpets and no drapes.
And then one August afternoon, he came into my office.
And he says, my god, Cook River's hot in here.
He said, why don't you get some drapes for those?
That was one of his little quirks.
He would come in, and something that you had mentioned to him before as an idea,
You'd think he had dismissed it.
But a week or so later, he would come back and say, why don't you look into this?
I'll never forget, Ergolic in chemistry was the soccer coach for A&M.
And he said, we need a new soccer field.
They quit letting them play on the drill field.
And Mr.
Rudder said, Edwin, I want you to find
Professor O'Gallick, a place for the soccer field.
And I came down to one place where the floral test garden is, right in there.
Nice slope, close to the gym, showers, everything.
And I brought a map in, and I showed it to Mr. O'Gallick.
I said, this is the place.
This is it.
He said, what is that symbol there, right in the middle of that field?
I said, oh, it's that big, old, ugly mesquite tree.
there's a mesquite tree in the middle of that field.
He said, you find something else.
I said, sir, it's a mesquite.
He said, have you ever been to Eden, Texas?
He says, now that's all we had.
He said, I love mesquite trees.
And later, when they were designing the president's home, he changed the whole driveway so the big old mesquites that are there to this day would not be disturbed.
But the point back to what I was saying a while ago about how it would come back to you,
He came in about two weeks later and he says, have you found a place for the soccer team?
I said, well, sir, the only place really that's within any kind of reason is the one I showed you.
He said, where the mesquite tree is?
I said, yes, sir.
He said, OK, we've got a court trip this coming week.
You tell Shorty Parsons that on Saturday night after dark that that tree be removed.
And Sod put over it, I don't want anybody to know the tree is gone.
He said, that'll be where our shark will fill.
He said, I'm surprised you didn't come up with that sooner.
But he had a great feeling for outdoor things.
And on the location of the house, I'll also remember about the tree.
You brought that to mind.
I said one time, why are you facing that house due east?
He said, because the sun is going to shine on Texas A&M every day, and I want to be the first one to see it.
That's good.
Let's go back to that Monday morning executive committee.
He inherited some of those folks, but he had an influence on some of the others.
One was Frank Hubert.
Do you have any idea of the relation?
Did the Huberts and Rudders have an old Austin relation, or do you know?
Possibly so, through the Texas Education Agency type of setup.
But I've never heard that specifically discussed.
When Hubert said something, did he listen?
Did Rudder listen, like I know he did when Benson
Yes, and Frank, I think he did because he had the same habit that he had on academic council.
Not academic council.
APC.
APC.
Which I admired.
He would listen to all the arguments and not say a word until he had it in his mind that the best route would be, and then he would speak up at the end.
And I think Mr.
Rudder...
appreciated that.
Uh, Benson, you didn't have to say anything.
You read him, read his face.
Uh, I remember one of the things that he challenged the deans with.
He says, Now we committed after the report that you were involved in, we're committed to excellence.
We're not gonna have that unless we have some really

world-renowned type of faculty and administrators here and he really pressed them to to find people and I remember Romanek was one of the really early ones and turned out to be an interesting choice but he was one and then later the man that was the National Academy of Science I can't remember his name precisely then Horace Byers but all of this started with Rudder's admonition I want some bell ringers in here
we've got to have them.
And if we get those, we can get the money that we need for research that you guys keep pounding about.
And another thing that he was adamant about is never losing
track of how important undergraduate teaching was.
I think one of his peeves was that faculty people, and deans included, probably were putting too much stress on the research aspect over the classroom teaching.
I don't think he was not opposed to research, but he was opposed to people losing track of how important it was that we have fine classroom teaching at the undergraduate level.
That was a pet peeve of his.
He did not like social climbers.
We're back to his personality traits now.
But you could see that at the dean's meetings and everywhere we would meet and talk.
He was more interested in seeing a person's results than he was idle chatter about it.

He laid great strength in knowing people, and I think the thing that I remember the best about him was he said, Edwin, you're going to have in your future life people that you work with or that work for you, and they're going to be disappointing to you, and they're going to screw up some things or cause problems.
He said, I think the best thing to do
whether it's education, business, or elsewhere.
When you get somebody new in there, maybe somebody you didn't even hire, but you have to work with them, find out what they do well.
And don't expect them to do anything besides that.
Find out what they don't do well.
Forget it.
You're not going to change them.
Find out what they do well and take advantage of that.
And you'll be happy, and they'll be happy.
And he kept saying that more than any other thing that I remember.
Now, his chief financial officer when you got there was Tom Cherry?
Right.
And Clark Diebel.
And what was their relationship?
It was excellent, if you're asking for it.
Tom was completely honest with him.
He was not afraid to buck an idea.
And he would argue points.
And he'd had such good experience with the, what was it?
He was with an airlines.
Yeah, Pan American Airlines or something.
He'd had a rich experience.
And Mr.
Rudder had the greatest confidence in him.
And then Tom leaned very heavily on Clark Diebel.
as the one to get the nitty-gritty work of the day done.
And Tom was freed up to do a lot of thought about directions that we were moving fiscally and so forth.
And Mr. Rutter had a high opinion of him.
And he simply would not sign anything unless Tom Cherry's TDC was on there.
Looking now for anecdotes.
Can you recall any interesting situation where something fiscally went wrong or was about to go wrong and maybe somebody grabbed it, found it, discovered it?
Let me think about that.
As we go on, I'll think of one.
Because there have to be where somebody comes in and, uh-oh, so-and-so is broke or,
We're about to go over the budget, or we just found a mathematical error, and we got a million dollars more than we thought we had.
There's got to be.
OK, I'll think of something on that line.
He and Diebel went back to the land office, and so they.
That's the German that he trusted.
OK, then in the student area, Hannigan was here as dean of students.
Another retired general.
Another retired general.
who, to me, didn't always understand Texas A&M well.
Did Mr. Rutter think that of Hannigan?

I think Mr. Rutter knew that Hannigan was going to, in his own way, make conservative decisions, that he was not going to come up with some wild-eyed program that was going to cost a great deal of money.
And the guys that worked for him were grossly underpaid.
I found that out later.
And the dean of students' job in Mr.

Rudder's eyes was maintain law and order and good study conditions, break up water fights, cut out pornography, cut out the drinking in the dormitories, and make everybody pretty well toe the line, as if it were a military encampment.
He never really was.
sold, in my mind, on a lot of the really good extracurricular things that were taking place, like at the MSC Council.
He never was really strong on that.
Of course, the core was his love, but like the student leadership conferences.
